Complete the following homework problems for Friday, February 2. Where appropriate, show work that justifies your answers for full credit.

  1. Show that \((1,1)\), \((4,1)\), \((3,-2)\), and \((0,-2)\) are the vertices of a parallelogram.

    I will use the fact that a quadrilateral is a parallelogram when opposite sides are congruent. The lengths of the four sides are computed as follows:

    • the distance from \((1,1)\) to \((4,1)\) is \(|1-4|=3\)
    • the distance from \((3,-2)\) to \((0,-2)\) is \(|3-0|=3\)
    • the distance from \((1,1)\) to \((0,-2)\) is \(\sqrt{(1-0)^2+(1--2)^2}=\sqrt{10}\)
    • the distance from \((3,-2)\) to \((4,1)\) is \(\sqrt{(3-4)^2+(-2-1)^2}=\sqrt{10}\)
    Comparing these side lengths to the quadrilateral as shown in the diagram below, we can see that opposite sides are congruent (same length), and so this is a parallelogram.

  2. Show that \((1,2)\), \((4,7)\), \((-6,13)\) and \((-9,8)\) are the vertices of a rectangle.

    I will use the fact that a quadrilateral is a rectangle when opposite sides are congruent and diagonals are congruent. The lengths of the four sides and the two diagonals are computed as follows:

    • the distance from \((1,2)\) to \((4,7)\) is \(\sqrt{(4-1)^2+(7-2)^2}=\sqrt{34}\)
    • the distance from \((4,7)\) to \((-6,13)\) is \(\sqrt{(4--6)^2+(7-13)^2}=\sqrt{136}\)
    • the distance from \((-6,13)\) to \((-9,8)\) is \(\sqrt{(-6--9)^2+(13-8)^2}=\sqrt{34}\)
    • the distance from \((-9,8)\) to \((1,2)\) is \(\sqrt{(-9-1)^2+(8-2)^2}=\sqrt{136}\)
    • the distance from \((-6,13)\) to \((1,2)\) is \(\sqrt{(-6-1)^2+(13-2)^2}=\sqrt{170}\) (diagonal)
    • the distance from \((-9,8)\) to \((4,7)\) is \(\sqrt{(-9-4)^2+(8-7)^2}=\sqrt{170}\) (diagonal)
    Comparing these side lengths to the quadrilateral as shown in the diagram below, we can see that opposite sides are congruent (same length) and the diagonals are congruent (same length), and so this is a rectangle.

  3. Show that \((3,3)\), \((0,2)\), \(\left(\frac{9}{5},-\frac{3}{5}\right)\), and \(\left(\frac{24}{5},\frac{2}{5}\right)\) are the vertices of a rhombus.

    I will use the fact that a quadrilateral is a rhombus when all four sides are congruent. The lengths of the four sides are computed as follows:

    • the distance from \((3,3)\) to \((0,2)\) is \(\sqrt{(3-0)^2+(3-2)^2}=\sqrt{10}\)
    • the distance from \((0,2)\) to \(\left(\frac{9}{5},-\frac{3}{5}\right)\) is \(\sqrt{(0-\frac{9}{5})^2+(2--\frac{3}{5})^2}=\sqrt{10}\)
    • the distance from \(\left(\frac{9}{5},-\frac{3}{5}\right)\) to \(\left(\frac{24}{5},\frac{2}{5}\right)\) is \(\sqrt{(\frac{9}{5}-\frac{24}{5})^2+(-\frac{3}{5}-\frac{2}{5})^2}=\sqrt{10}\)
    • the distance from \(\left(\frac{24}{5},\frac{2}{5}\right)\) to \((3,3)\) is \(\sqrt{(\frac{24}{5}-3)^2+(\frac{2}{5}-3)^2}=\sqrt{10}\)
    Comparing these side lengths to the quadrilateral as shown in the diagram below, we can see that all four sides are congruent (same length), and so this is a rhombus.
